data.title: Update Atom build directory in build instructions
data.body: The atom build directory has been changed. The new build directory is `out/Atom`.

data.title: Cache regexes in LanguageMode.prototype.getRegexForProperty
data.body:
This adds a simple layer of caching into `LanguageMode.prototype.getRegexForProperty` to avoid allocating `OnigRegExp` objects when e.g. calling `autoDecreaseIndentForBufferRow` (which is called for each line when performing a multi-cursor edit).
#### Before

![screen shot 2016-02-18 at 14 31 43](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/13144733/a71cfc62-d64c-11e5-8bf6-aa67be04f6d4.png)

_(Total: `~ 293ms`, benchmark performed by editing 1500 lines, writing 5 characters)_
#### After

![screen shot 2016-02-18 at 14 29 03](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/13144735/aae39284-d64c-11e5-9fcd-c2a74b571b92.png)

_(Total: `~ 135ms`, ~ 2x speedup :racehorse:)_

For the same edit, the method now takes `~ 135ms` to execute, but most of that time (`> 80ms`) is spent in getting the scope descriptor for a certain buffer position. That should get better with @nathansobo's improvements at the `DisplayLayer`, making `autoDecreaseIndentForBufferRow` a pretty cheap function call.

/cc: @atom/core

data.title: Roadmap link - error 404
data.body:
How to reproduce: `Help -> Roadmap`.
Tested on Atom 1.5.3.

data.title: Cannot close tab in latest bracket
data.body:
MAC OS, every time I try to close the tab with the x button in the tab, it will open a new tab. It has been after I upgraded to 
Release 1.6 build 1.6.0-16680 (release 3df0ac6fa) 
build timestamp: Tue Jan 12 2016 05:35:00 GMT-0800

data.title: Tooltips do not appear/disappear correctly.
data.body: If you (on Mac) command+tab to Atom, and your cursor just happens to land on a tab, the blue hover dialog pops up. This is distracting and hovers should only ever be triggered if the mouse _stopped_ on a hover target.

data.title: Prevent hangs on opening files with long lines by only tokenizing the first 2000 characters of a line
data.body: Works with https://github.com/atom/first-mate/pull/67 to prevent hangs on opening files with extremely long lines. Should fix many of the issues in https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/979.

However, VCS ignored paths are not showing up in the navigation tree (e.g. files listed in .gitignore).

data.title: Atom leaves image of itself imprinted on other windows when losing focus in Windows 7
data.body:
When changing focus from the active atom window to another application's window there is an image/imprint of atom stuck on the screen. Some notes:
- If a certain part of the newly active window is refreshed in some way (mouseover a button, panning a map, scrolling, etc.) that section of the window will show through. 
- Moving the newly active window only removes the atom imprint on sections that leave the view of the screen. 
- Changing focus via the taskbar does not create this issue. 
- Minimising atom does not create this issue. 
- This does not affect all types of windows (ie. Chrome is not affected, but ArcGIS is - seems to only affect Windows GUI based applications). 
- This issue is also present in safe mode.
- Using the most up-to-date version (1.5.3)
- This has been present since I installed atom several months ago.

Refer to the attached image.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10606760/13130603/6207d07e-d639-11e5-8fdd-eebd2a07f3bc.png)

data.title: Avoid Windows 260-character path limits in script\clean
data.body: Kind of experimental but currently clean on Windows fails most of the time because of the path lengths.

data.title: Avoid emitting config events while loading packages
Terminate pending state for opened file if pending option is false
data.body:
@joshaber pointed out that opening a file from fuzzy-finder currently does not make a pending pane item permanent. This PR makes it such that if you open a file without the `pending` option and the file is currently opened in pending state, the pending state will be terminated. 

TODO: Merge PRs for find-and-replace and tree-view once this is on stable. I simplified code in these packages by opening items without `pending` option rather than explicitly invoking `terminatePendingState`

ACTUAL

data.title: Atom deems regexes with atomic groups or possessive quantifiers invalid
data.body:
Atomic grouping and possessive quantifiers are _extremely_ useful in regular expression. Supporting them can **only** speed up regex evaluation, especially for grammars that use them, as well as reduce the number of Find and Replace hangs that kill an Atom window.

Consider the regex `\b(integer|integral|integrity|insert|int|in)\b`matched against `integers`. The engine will match the first alternative, fail at the `\b`, then backtrack into the group and repeatedly match, fail, and backtrack through every single alternative, even matching the group in the last two cases only to fail at the `\b` again. This is quite a lot of work just to figure out `integers` isn't in our list of words. On the other hand, the atomic group `\b(?>integer|integral|integrity|insert|int|in)\b` will immediately give up matching the group at the second `\b` and never backtrack.

Consider also the regexes `"[^"]*"` and `"[^"]*+"` matched against `"aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa`. Both fail, but the former backtracks through the _entire_ string, while the second fails immediately thanks to possessive quantifiers. When such behavior is desired (often for order-dependent parameters), this makes a huge difference for performance.

Both of these are simplistic examples, but it's easy to imagine more realistic cases where the patterns getting backtracked through contain multiple alternatives, subgroups, character classes, lookaheads, or all of these.

In particular, I remember that switching to possessive quantifiers when writing a parser for Foxboro's ICC format reduced the parse time for a complete CP280 program from ~10min to a few seconds, merely by eliminating backtracking. Unfortunately I can't publish this as an Atom grammar, because Atom doesn't support atomics or possessives (or [string anchors](9146)).

If this issue is due to Atom's reliance on the crippled javascript regex spec, then it's time to junk it for one suited to the 21st century (or even the 20th).

data.title: ENH: Find in find results output
data.body:
In Sublime, you can search in the search results output. This searches the filenames of the results as well as the match text. This is very useful when you have a vague search with many results. I use this a lot for searching for function definitions.

The steps in Sublime are:
ctrl+shift+F > search for stringA > Shows normal search output
ctrl+F > search for stringB > Searches in the search output only

Currently searching Atom search output does not seem to happen, but the "No results for <searchTerm>" is updated.

data.title: Regex replace, re-escaping the backslash multiple times in consecutive replacements
data.body:
When escaping the backslash `\` to be inserted/replaced in a file, it will escape it multiple times until the the backslash is not shown anymore

For example when using the regex: `(\(\d\)(\s|\w)+)` and the replace text `\\textbf{$1}` on the text:

> (3) Normal—Is able to ambulate for 10 steps heel to toe with no
> staggering.
> (2) Mild impairment—Ambulates 7–9 steps.
> (1) Moderate impairment—Ambulates 4 –7 steps.
> (0) Severe impairment—Ambulates less than 4 steps heel to toe or
> cannot perform without assistance.

It will end up with:

> \textbf{(3) Normal}—Is able to ambulate for 10 steps heel to toe with no
> staggering.
> `     `extbf{(2) Mild impairment}—Ambulates 7–9 steps.
> ` `extbf{(1) Moderate impairment}—Ambulates 4 –7 steps.
> ` `extbf{(0) Severe impairment}—Ambulates less than 4 steps heel to toe or
> cannot perform without assistance.

If we keep adding backslash, we can see that the error comes from reinterpreting the regex again and again, after it has been already interpreted. For example, if we change the replace text with `\\\\textbf{$1}`, then we end up with this:

> \\textbf{(3) Normal}—Is able to ambulate for 10 steps heel to toe with no
> staggering.
> \textbf{(2) Mild impairment}—Ambulates 7–9 steps.
> `  `extbf{(1) Moderate impairment}—Ambulates 4 –7 steps.
> `  `extbf{(0) Severe impairment}—Ambulates less than 4 steps heel to toe or
> cannot perform without assistance.

data.title: Create `atom` Babel Preset
data.body:
By creating an `atom` babel preset that core and packages can use, we introduce the possibility for slowly dialing back the number of transforms required during transpilation as the version of node bundled in Electron progresses.

It also provides a vector for possible optimizations to be introduced across all atom packages using babel, by writing new transforms focused on performance.

Related to #10860.

data.title: Compare markers instead of ranges in Selection
data.body:
This largely reduces the overhead of converting ranges/points from native to javascript objects.
#### Before

![screen shot 2016-02-17 at 16 26 23](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/13114303/40bbd43e-d593-11e5-986c-e0251c23093c.png)

_(Total: `~ 1040ms`, benchmarks performed by editing 1500 lines, writing 5 characters)_
#### After

![screen shot 2016-02-17 at 16 22 54](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/13114297/3b4f1e98-d593-11e5-967f-733af53cff8d.png)

_(Total: `~ 65ms`, 16x speedup :racehorse: :racehorse: :racehorse:)_

Props to @maxbrunsfeld for suggesting this fix! :clap: 

/cc: @atom/core

data.title: Fix for Default Directory Provider incorrectly identifying file paths as URLs on Windows
data.body:
Atom's `default-directory-provider` incorrectly identified Windows file paths (e.g. c:\users\paul\text.txt) as URL's. This has a knock-on effect for features such as the Tree View, which shows individually opened files as though they are directories (as opposed to the correct functionality, whereby Tree View shows the file's parent directory and highlights the opened file).

This was because the module was checking for the presence of a protocol in the path passed to it in order to determine whether it was a local file path or a URL (such as atom://config/something). Unfortunately, on Windows the drive letter (e.g. `c:`) was identified as a protocol.

The fix put in place replaces the check for a protocol with one that checks for a hostname. In valid URLs this should come back as a non-empty string, but on Windows it'll come back empty meaning the module correctly identifies the string as a file path.

Tested on Mac and Windows.

Linked tree view issue is [here](https://github.com/atom/tree-view/issues/471)

data.title: Compute line foldability lazily
data.body:
Understanding whether a row can be folded or not requires to scan surrounding lines and it's relatively slow. As you might imagine, doing so for every changed line after a multi-cursor edit can become quite painful as the amount of edited lines increases. For this reason, with this PR we now compute foldability on-demand (lazily) only for on-screen lines.
#### Before

![screen shot 2016-02-17 at 15 24 01](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/13112699/3e149556-d58c-11e5-9341-1c129b6c2bc4.png)

_(Total: `~ 482ms`, benchmark performed by editing 1500 lines, writing 5 characters)_
#### After

![screen shot 2016-02-17 at 15 22 22](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/13112872/f08a9e24-d58c-11e5-8291-65ff8e3c3911.png)

_(Total: `0 ms` in `handleBufferChange`, and the impact on the rendering path is negligible thanks to 2a35d19 :racehorse: :racehorse: :racehorse:)_

There's one caveat I illustrated in 90c75fd which needs to be discussed, but I feel like it _might_ be addressed separately and was not a problem introduced with these changes.

/cc: @atom/core

data.title: Update CI To Node 5.x
data.body:
#9627 introduces Chrome 47 and Node 5.1.1. It would be nice to have CI match the node version bundled with Electron.

Given that:
- Electron bundles node
- Electron doesn't only use stable node, it tries to track v8
- Atom is comprised of Electron, core code, bundled packages, and npm modules
- apm is really just a wrapper around `npm`

Then I think we should formulate a strategy to:
- Try to lock in the same version of node in CI for core, bundled packages, and npm packages
- Try to use the same npm version bundled with the aforementioned version of node in apm
- When specifying node versions in CI, try to lock to the major / minor, but allow later patch versions (e.g. `~5.1.1`, as opposed to `5` or `^5.1.1`)

The goal of this would be to try to be somewhat deterministic in the builds, but this is somewhat dependent on the core Atom build servers being upgradeable, as releases are still generated there.

Doing this consistently would also have the side effect of allowing us to establish an `atom` babel preset, that can be used to slowly dial back the transforms required during transpilation as the version of node continues to progress and more ES6 functionality is bundled in.

data.title: New file in project folder is not searchable
data.body: When a new file is created in a project folder either by copy paste or using save as option. It is not searchable immediately using Command+T on Mac. After a brief moment (couple of minutes) it started appearing in the search results.

data.title: Update grunt-electron-installer to latest version
data.body: This gets us the latest version of Squirrel updater with many Windows fixes.
